Situation1: Communicate openly to resolve conflicts or misunderstandings.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story: I stared at my phone, my brother’s message still unread. We’d argued last night—something stupid, but it had left a bitter taste. He wanted to talk, to clear the air, and I knew I should call him back, listen, and try to fix things. That’s what a good brother does: communicates, builds trust, doesn’t let misunderstandings fester. But my laptop screen glared at me, the code for the core module half-finished. My team was waiting; the whole project was stalled because of me. Emails kept pinging in, my manager asking for updates, teammates growing impatient. I felt the weight of their expectations—if I didn’t deliver, the timeline would slip, and everyone would pay for it. My mind spun between the two worlds: the brother who needed to reach out, the engineer who needed to deliver. I could almost hear both voices in my head, each demanding my attention, each certain their need was more urgent. My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn, as the minutes ticked by.
